The cry is, whose is the fault, where lies the cause of blunders so that an idiot would not commit them?

We have many rumors to which I must not tongue.
But I may say that the general report is that McClellan was not apprised of the intended movement at Edward's Ferry, or at least that its character was not communicated to him. He is said to be extremely indignant at it.

div3.head: Military absentees.
div3.p:
We are informed that General Beauregard has issued a general order to the Colonels commanding the different regiments of the army of the Potomac, directing them to furnish the sheriffs of the towns and counties from which their respective companies come, with a list of absentees from their commands, and requiring the sheriffs forth with to arrest and return to their camps all such persons who may be fit for duty.
We have noticed a detachment of soldiers in Richmond for a day or two past, who are charged with the duty of apprehending all stragglers from the army and forwarding them to Manassas.
It is said that these vigilant "detectives" spare neither rank nor condition, but arrest a Major or a Captain with as little scruple as they do a private.
The rule does not apply to those who have proper passes to go home within a given period, or surgeon's certificates to show that they are unfit for duty; but the action of Gen. Beauregard shows that vigorous measures are to be applied, and absentees will see the propriety of reporting themselves voluntarily for duty.

div3.head: Virginia traitors.
div3.p:
The Baltimore papers of the 26th October announce that "Col." Joseph Segar, for many years a resident at Old Point, has been elected to Congress by the Union voters of Eastern Virginia." This bogus election was doubtless accomplished by Lincoln's soldiers at Fortress Monroe and Newport News, aided, Perhaps, by runaway negroes, and is intended as a partial compensation for the destruction of "Col. Joseph Segar's" property, as well as a reward for his treachery.
The same authority informs us that the traitors in Western Virginia voted on the 24th on the question of the division of the State.
Wheeling cast an "overwhelming" vote in favor of division, and the report is that the "interior" shows a still greater unanimity.

div3.head: The Federal armada.
div3.p:
Federal advices from Fortress Monroe, as late as Friday last, represent that the number of vessels of all kinds in the naval expedition is about 100, and that the marine and land forces on board number from 30,000 to 40,000.
A Baltimore paper expresses the opinion that it is not destined for any port very far South.
The fleet is under the command of Commodores Dupont, and the troops under the command of Gen. Sherman.

div3.head: Hon. R. K. Mende.
div3.p: The Petersburg Express announces, upon unquestionable authority, that the Hon. R. Kidder Meade, late United States Minister to Brazil, has arrived safely in one of the ports of the Confederate States.

div3.head: Latest from the North

argument.p: the retreat of the Federals from Edward's Ferry — the Federal loss at ball's Bluff-- capture of a Brig by a Confederate privateer — affairs at Fortress Monroe, &c.

div3.p:
At a late hour last night we were placed in possession of files of the Northern papers as late as Saturday last, 24th instant, certainly later than any date which had been received in this city an to that time.
Below will be found our summary of news taken from their columns:

div4.head: The retreat of the Federals from Edward's Ferry.
div4.p: The special Washington correspondent of the Philadelphia Inquirer gives the following account of the retreat of Banks and Stone from Edward's Ferry:

q.p:
Gen. McClellan's headquarters were at Edwards's Ferry on Thursday morning. Since closing my dispatch yesterday Gens. McClellan and Banks returned from the Virginia side of the Potomac, and at about ten o'clock rode with a strong cavalry escort up to Conrad's Ferry.
Our troops had been all brought from the Island over to the Maryland shore, and the Virginia shore was thickly covered with the Confederates.
They made no attempt to fire upon our troops, but were very bold in showing themselves.
No shots were fired by our men, and, after consultation, all of our troops, except a picket guard, were marched to Poolesville.
The appearance of some of them was the most distressing sight we ever witnessed.

Many of them were nearly naked; some had on nothing but overcoats; some only a pair of pants, and but few with shoes; most of them were without arms and ammunition.
Most of the wounded had been sent to Poolesville and to the nearest camps Captain Vaughan, who was sent over with a flag of truce, to get permission to bring off the dead, and render the wounded what assistance was in our power, had not returned up to the hour which we write (eleven A. M,) and is no doubt sent to the enemy's rear as a prisoner.

About four P. M. yesterday, the Confederates showed themselves in force upon the hill, about two miles and a half towards Leesburg where they had thrown up a dirt fort.
It was soon found that they had two regiments there, and at the same time a large force was, sported advancing on our left, on the left of Goose Creek, from the direction of Fairfax Court-House.
Our force was again prepared to receive them.
Gens. McClellan and Bank, who had just arrived, took up a position on the high bluff on this side.
From there we could see the whole country before us for two or three miles back, and some eight up and down the country.

Our batteries were ranged along the hill, and Gen. McClellan on foot, with a large marine glass, watched the whole field.
Every moment he was issuing orders to one battery to watch that road and that field, and to be ready to fire as soon as the word was given — A large force of infantry were called up and marched to the river, some of them upon the double-quick.

Several batteries were taken down, and a fleet of canal boats were run out from the canal into the river, to cross the men in. Every fifteen minutes messengers would come over and report from our pickets, and it soon became evident that we would not be attacked before morning, and the enemy were only drawing up their reinforcements in order to surround our little force, and either take all prisoners or else enact the Conrad's Ferry disaster over again.

About 6 P. M. orders were issued to have the troops all brought back, and those who had embarked to go over were unloaded, and returned to their camps.
Then commenced the work of bringing them back safely.
It was done by canal boats.
They would be loaded and then poled across, landing half a mile below the point from where they started.
All reached here at 4 A. M., and the appearance of some of them was painful, indeed.--They had stood in line of battle from 12 to 14 hours without moving, and without water or food.
They had no sleep for two days and nights, and were nearly exhausted.
Some dragged their muskets along by the end, and seemed to sleep as they walked along.

The Minnesota First were the nearest exhausted of any, but we heard no grumbling.
All seemed thankful to have got over safe; not a man was injured in the re-crossing, nor any baggage lost; everything came over safe.--Generals Gorman and Stone personally superintended the crossing, and were the last to leave.
General Gorman has been in the saddle for two days and nights.

About daylight a squad of 4 or 5 men came running down to the shore, and, with cuirasses, were seen by our men, who found themselves left, and were afraid they were lost.
A boat was sent over after them.
The Confederates had not found out that we had retired, or, at least had not made their appearance then.

About nine o'clock their cavalry scouts were seen ranging along the opposite hills, out did not approach nearer than a mile, and none were seen on the fort.
A wood to our right, distant about two miles, is reported to contain the Mississippi brigade, who were in the battle at Bali's Bluff.

We are watching momentarily for some important move.
It now looks as though we would have the grand engagement of the campaign near here.
The Confederates had a large force last night, less than three miles off.

Twelve O'clock, Noon.--A force of Confederates can now be seen mounting guns upon the forts.
They have four pieces, but have as yet made no other demonstrations

div4.p:
A correspondent of the New York Tribune writing under date of "Edward's Ferry, Sunday, 6 P. M.," (20th,) gives the following graphic particulars of the engagement at Leesburg.
The manner in which Gen. Baker was killed coincides with our account of the affair, published a few days ago:

q.p:
At this juncture Gen.Baker, who had dismounted from his horse, and was advancing at the head of his command, coolly, but resolutely encouraging his men, received a ball through his head, killing him instantly.
The General's blood bespattered Capt Crowning shield, who stood beside him at the moment.
He never spoke.
His body was immediately taken to the rear by his men, who freely wept at their loss.
He was placed in a scow and transported to the island, and thence to the Maryland shore.
His remains were sent to Edward's Ferry, and thence to Poolsville.--His horse, which had been left standing, was afterwards shot.
A small canvass satchel, containing his papers, I saw in the hands of a young man to whom they were delivered shortly before he fell.

This was the turning point of the battle.--The Confederates were five to one of the Union force, and the latter were finally ordered to leave the field.
The retreat was made after the Bull Run pattern, with slight improvements, the men rolling, sliding, and almost turning summersaults down hill, to escape the galling fire which now assailed them from all points.
The Confederates were constantly reinforced, screaming like furies at each onset.
Before retreating they threw the six-pounder down the hill into the river.--The howitzers were left on the field, and fell into the enemy's hands.
The Fifteenth and Twentieth Massachusetts regiments suffered very severely, losing a large part of their numbers in killed and wounded.

The Tammany regiment covered itself with glory.
Captain O'Merra often rallied his command, throwing defiance into the very teeth of the enemy, and showing the Confederates that he could scream equal to the worst of them.
Captain O'Meara took charge of the landing, and refused to let any but wounded men enter the boat, ordering the sound troops to go back and pepper the Confederates.
His conduct was very gallant throughout, evincing a true and lofty courage.
Lieut. Messer took command of the scow, and continued to ferry over the wounded, who poured down the hill.
Several times the Confederates fired upon him as he was crossing with the wounded men. The fourth boat load was capsized by the men rushing into it in too great numbers, and the whole party, about fifty in number, well and wounded, were precipitated into the stream.
Ten of the party, at least, were drowned.
A great many tried to swim the river, and sank from exhaustion.
One half of those who are missing were drowned in this manner.
It is not yet known how many of our men have fallen into their hands.
The destruction of life has been for greater, in proportion to the numbers engaged, than at Bad Run!

div4.head: [the Associated press Dispatches.]
div4.p:
Edward's Ferry, Oct. 24,P. M.--The rebels during this afternoon, were busily engaged in and around their fort between Leesburg and the river fronting Edward's Ferry.
They had previously removed their ordnance, but from the movements observed, it was judged they were engaged in replacing them.
The fort is located on the crest of the first range of hills from the river, several hundred yards to the left of a piece of woods with a breastwork, constructing it well, and extending into or in rear of the woods.

To the rear of this elevation is Leesburg.
Parties of horsemen have at different times during the day, come up to the fortification, and viewed our batteries ranged along the hills above the ferry.

Between the fort hill and Leesburg evidently rests a large rebel force.
The smoke from their camp fires has been discoverable all day. It is believed, however, that their main body lies near to and directly opposite the ferry.
They have not exposed themselves in any force, but their pickets and small reconnoitering parties have several times been seen.
During the afternoon a train consisting of about one hundred wagons, appeared on a more distant hill to the right of Leesburg, and encamped here under the lee of a piece of woods.

Towards dusk a considerable body of cavalry were seen approaching a farm house near the river, a mile above the ferry, where, du- ring the afternoon, several bodies of officers had paid visits.
It is thought that this house has been occupied as a headquarters of some brigade or divisions.

The regiments engaged in the affair of Monday have not yet completed their reports of the losses sustained.
They will be made as perfect as possible, and be returned tomorrow.
The various regiments located in this region are endeavoring to make themselves as comfortable as the limited facilities of the country will admit.

Still Later.--Last night our scouts went over the river, and picketed the shore for half a mile back north of Goose Creek.
Not a sign of man or horse was heard, except the splashing of the cars of a boat some distance up the river.

This forenoon the rebel pickets are seen at various points on and near the river, above the ferry.
Some are mounted, while others are on foot.
No large bodies have been perceived, but it is known that they are concealed by the wooded range of hills half a mile back from the river.
They till occupy the fort, but apparently not in any great force, although a very heavy body lies directly in their rear.

At midnight there was continued firing at the mouth of the Monocracy.
It resulted from the shelling of a rebel camp by our batteries.
The enemy did not reply to our shots with any large guns.
At headquarters the affair is not spoken of as any great significance — The result of our firing has not yet been fully ascertained, beyond the fact that the enemy retreated from their position.
Their number is represented to have been small.

Privates Tuttle, Clemens, Molher, and Reymond, of the 3d Regiment Wisconsin Vols., were killed, and Private Ross, Co. C, 3d Wisconsin, Corporal Pratt, Co. A, 28th Pennsylvania Regiment, were taken prisoners by the rebels.

[The foregoing confirms accounts received in this city that the enemy crossed over into Virginia subsequent to the battle of Leesburg, and afterwards made a hasty retreat.-- Eds.
Dis.]

div4.head: The Federal loss at ball's Bluff.
div4.p:
The Baltimore South, of the 25th, learns that the loss of 620 on the Federal side at Ball's Bluff, reported in the Northern papers of Friday last, was based only upon partial returns.
Up to midnight Thursday night, the 24th, full accounts had not been received at the Federal War Department.

The correspondent of the Philadelphia Inquirer says that in company C, of the California Regiment, out of 65 men only 15 had reported themselves; company D lost 32 men, and company G 45 men. The same correspondent says that eight companies of the California Regiment were in the fight, who, in pursuance of orders from Gen. Banks, went over under Gen. Baker to reinforce the 15th and 20th Massachusetts and the Tammany Regiment, which were fiercely engaged.
He continues:

q.p:
The report that was handed in at the headquarters of Baker's Brigade, on the morning of the 22d, stated there were 322 men missing, and nine officers of the California regiment.
The Tammany Regiment consisted of between 800 and 1,000 men, and but 400 had returned up to Wednesday morning.

Gen. Stone issued the orders for Col. Baker to cross the Potomac at Conrad's Ferry at sunrise on Monday morning. When Col. Baker arrived there with his regiment, be found that the Tammany regiment, from New York, and the Fifteenth Massachusetts, under Col. Cogshall, had already crossed in advance.

Colonel Baker immediately proceeded to cross, and soon after sunrise was on the Virginia side with his command.
By the time Colonel Baker and his men had got into marching order, the two regiments that had crossed before him were already some distance in advance, and were engaged by a large number of Confederates and compelled to fall back on the California regiment, the Confederates following them up.

Being reinforced by this regiment, they then rallied, and drove the enemy back in a savage manner for some distance, until, getting in the cover of the woods, they compelled us to retire again.
Thus three different times they went and came, and finally, when the Confederates in the woods were reinforced by several thousand from Leesburg, they proved too strong for us to withstand effectually.

div4.head: From Fortress Monroe.
div4.p:
The Federal accounts from Fortress Monroe are filled with speculations in regard to the fleet which has recently left Hampton Roads.
We subjoin the following telegraphic dispatch:

q.p:
Fortress Monroe, Oct. 24.--The weather to-day has been most favorable for completing the enormous preparations for the expedition.
It will probably said to-night.
All the armed vessels and transports have now arrived, and Hampton Roads presents, especially at night, a magnificent appearance.
The steamer Spaulding will not leave for Hatteras before Sunday.
Col. J. Segar. for many years a resident at Old Point, has been elected to Congress by the Union voters of Eastern Virginia.
Among the passengers who visited Old Point on Wednesday were four nurses for the fleet in Hampton Roads.

On Thursday a rebel tug, bearing a flag of truce, made its appearance above Sewell's Point, but was not permitted to approach or hold communication with any of the Federal vessels anchored in the stream.
Gen. Wool has notified the rebels repeatedly that all communication by flags of truce will be discontinued until the fleet has sailed.

bibl.n: The Federal accounts from Fortress Monroe

div4.head: From Missouri.
div4.p: The following Northern dispatches in regard to the progress of the war in Missouri are too palpably false to justify us in reminding our readers that due caution should be observed in placing a proper estimate upon newspaper reports from that side of the Potomac:

q.p: St. Louis, Oct. 25.--A Jefferson City dispatch to the Democrat reports, that it was rumored at Tipton, and believed, that Lane and Montgomery have intercepted McCulloch's rebel force, and cut his whole army to pieces.

St. Louis, Oct. 24.--Col. Morgan, with 220 men of the 18th Missouri regiment, and two pieces of artillery, had a fight with some 400 rebels, on Big Hurricane Creek, Carrol county, last Saturday, killing 14, taking eight prisoners, and putting the balance to flight.
Col. Morgan had 14 wounded.
St Louis, Oct. 25.--At the latest accounts Gen. Price was retreating towards Greenfield, in Dade county. Gen. Siegel's advance guard was near Bolivar on Tuesday evening, and his main body at Quincy.

General Seigel was as far South as General Price's rebel army, but some twenty-five miles east of him, and evidently aiming for Springfield, to cut off his retreat South, while General Lane was only two day's march north of him.
Gen, Lane's forces were at Osceola, and Gen. S gis's entire command was but one day's march behind.

Fremont is at Pommedette River, en route for Quincey.
Gen. Pope was marching on Leesville, via Sedalia.
A detachment of U. S. cavalry broke up a rebel camp at Buffalo Mills on Tuesday night, killing seventeen and wounding a large number, also taking ninety prisoners and a large number of horses.

div4.head: Capture by a privateer — the Brig Granada taken by the Sallie.
div4.p: From the New York Post, of the 24th of October, we take the following:

q.p:
The brig Granada, Captain Pettingill, from Nuevitas to New York, was taken as a prize by the privateer Sallie, off Charleston, on the 13th inst., in latitude 33, longitude 71, at midnight. The captain, second mate and two seamen of the Granada, were taken on board the privateer, and on the 15th, in latitude 29, longitude 70, were transferred to the British schooner Greyhound, Captain Gamage, from St. Domingo city, and brought to this port.--Mr. Russell Butterfield, the first officer of the brig, was detained on board the vessel to navigate her into Charleston or Savannah.
The cook — a white man-- and one of the seamen volunteered on board the privateer.

The Granada had a cargo of 400 hogsheads of sugar, melado and molasses, and a quantity of cedar, and was consigned to Messrs. Thomas Owen & Son, of this city.
The privateers took from the captain his clothes and nautical instruments.
The privateer sallie is a fore-and-aft schooner of about 140 tons, painted black, mounts one gun amidships, and has a crew of forty men, and is commanded by Capt. Libby, formerly of the ship Gondar, of Charleston, So. Ca.
She ran the blockade from Charleston on the 10th instant.
She was formerly the schooner Virginia, of Brookhaven, and when last seen was steering to the Eastward.
The Granada was built at Cape Elizabeth, Maine, in 1856, rated A2, 255 tons burthen, and was owned or consigned to Thomas Owen & Son, of this city.

div4.head: The Privateersmen of the Savannah.
div4.p: The New York Post, of the 24th inst., has the following in regard to the trial of the captain and crew of the privateer Savannah:

q.p:
The trial of the privateermen of the Savannah was resumed this morning in the United States Circuit Court in this city.
The court-room was crowded with spectators.--Baker, the privateer Captain, took a seat at the table occupied by his counsel, and on being presented with a copy of the Charleston Mercury, perused it for some time, apparently with the deepest interest.
His features wore a more stoical expression than during the proceedings of yesterday.
Young Passailingue, an object of almost equal interest, exhibited his usual buoyancy of spirits, but occasionally assumed an appearance of much gravity — Harriston, who, when arraigned for indictment, appeared very uneasy, is now quite self-possessed.
At times he is apparently altogether unconcerned.
All the counsel were present.
The testimony was then resumed, but no now facts elicited.

div4.head: Arrival of the Keystone State with the privateer Salvor.
div4.p:
Philadelphia, Oct. 25,--The U. S. steamer Keystone State, Capt. Scott, with the prize steamer Salvor in tow, arrived at the navy-yard at 6 o'clock this evening.
When off Cape Hatteras on Monday she encountered a severe gale, lasting until Tuesday, during which the Keystone State separated from her prize in charge of Lieut. Donaldson.
The prize drifted to the westward and the steamer to the eastward, separating them 167 miles before the steamer could go in search of her.--When found she was steering on the direct course.

The Keystone State left Philadelphia on the 19th of July, and has since traveled fifteen thousand miles in search of the privateer Sumter.
She arrived at Port-au-Prince five days after the Sumter left the last place.
She heard of the Sumter at Surinam, where she was from the 19th of August to the 1st of September. The Keystone State arrived at Surinam on the 19th of September.
She spoke the United States steamer Flag off Charleston on last Saturday--all well.

div4.head: Important telegraphic Achievement — completion of the telegraph to the Pacific coast--First Flash from San Francisco.
div4.p: New York, Oct. 25.--The following congratulatory dispatch, signalizing the completion of telegraphic communication between the shores of the Atlantic and Pacific coast, was received this afternoon:

opener.salute: To the Mayor of New York:

div5.p:
San Francisco to New York sends greetings, and congratulates her on the completion of the enterprise which connects the Pacific with the Atlantic!
May the prosperity of both cities be increased thereby, and the projectors of this important work meet with honor and reward.

div4.head: Latest from Fort Pickens.
div4.p: New York, Oct. 25--Mr. Packhard, a native of Maine, and a fugitive from Florida, who arrived here by the steamer McClellan, communicates the fact that Col. Brown had made all his arrangements to open the batteries of Fort Pickens upon Pensacola on the 16th, but was prevented by the affair at the mouth of the Mississippi, which rendered it necessary that two ships which were to have taken part in the action should go to the aid of the fleet there.

div4.head: Probable release of three more prisoners from Fort Lafayette.
div4.p: The New York Tribunes, Oct. 25, has the following paragraph:

q.p:
One of the Deputy U. S. Marshals went down to Fort Lafayette yesterday afternoon, with the necessary documents, offering the opening of the prison doors to three of the gentlemen therein confined, subject, of course, to their taking the oath of allegiance.
The names did not transpire last night, as the officer had not returned.

div4.head: An incident of the Fulton street (N. Y.) prayer meeting.
div4.p:
A Northern paper contains the following incident which occurred in one of their prayer meetings lately.
Our readers will, perhaps, feel highly gratified at the honor done Richmond by the distinguished disciple of "Orville (Awful) Gardner," in determining (as he did at the battle of Bull Run) to take up his abode in our midst:

q.p:
One day recently the Fulton street prayer meeting was near closing, when a man in the uniform of an officer of the army arose and said: "I cannot let this meeting close without saying a word.
I came home from the battle-field of Bull Run injured, and saved from instant death as almost by a miracle.--I was in the battle of the 21st of July, and in the thickest of the fight, and such were the circumstances of my escape that I was led to think on my ways.
I have been a wicked man. When there was any wickedness going on I was sure to be foremost in it. Coming home wounded, I had time to ask myself why I had been spared.
I was struck down by a squad of the Black Horse cavalry.
I never expected to get away alive" After the meeting had closed, some one asked the officer, "Do you know Jim Irving of your regiment?" "What!
the old comrade of the worst fighters of the city?
he and Orville Gardner at their head?
I guess I know him." "What sort of a man is he in the camp?" "His is the most beautiful Christian character I ever saw. I never saw anything like it." "Does he drink rum?" "Not a drop." "Does he attend prayer meetings?" "Always will have one going." "Where is he now?" "In prison at Richmond, because he considered it his duty to stand to the last, and he was taken." "Do you know he was accustomed to attend these meetings?" "I have often heard him speak of these meetings with the profoundest delight.
If Jim Irving is not a changed man, I do not know who is Not a man in the regiment could be found who does not know him, and does not believe him to be a Christian."

div4.head: Characteristic Yankee Romance.
div4.p: The Lowell Citizen and News publishes the following incident:

q.p:
The circumstances detailed below come from a quarter which leaves no doubt of their being quite reliable.
A man who has carried on business in this city for some ten years past, accumulating considerable property, and living apparently in as much connubial felicity as is vouchsafed to folks on the average in the married state, has lately been smoked out in the following way: Within a year or two his wife suspected too much familiarity between him and a certain other woman, contrary to the law in such cases made and provided, and set a police detective on the scent in order to the establishing of proofs sufficient to secure for her a divorce, provided her surmises should be found correct.
His investigations discovered too much, for he found the man had a wife in New Hampshire, whom he married before coming to this city, and deserted in three weeks afterward.
She, however, had married a second time, like himself.
The second wife, finding that she was not lawfully married, and therefore not likely to be divorced, preferred a compromise; the man gave her half the property, dividing some $18,000 between them, and they separated.
Taken altogether, it's a curious case, rather complicated, but yet one of the too common proofs that this is a wicked world.

div4.head: A suspected Individual re-arrested.
div4.p: The following is another charming illustration of the perfect freedom of speech and action enjoyed at the North:

q.p:
Mr. Cyrus F. Sargent, of Yarmouth, Me., who was recently arrested by order of the Secretary of War, and discharged by order of Secretary Seward, was on Monday re-arrested by Deputy Marshal Heald, while in the cars on his way South, and was taken in charge by Mr. Heald, to be conveyed to Fort Lafayette.
While on the route between Portland and Portsmouth, Mr. Sargent drew a revolver upon Heald and defied him to detain him. This movement was observed by Col. John Goddard, who was in the car, and he drew another revolver upon Sargent, which quieted him, and he gave up his revolver.

div4.head: Incident at Bull Run.
div4.p: A correspondent of one of the Lincoln journals communicates the following improbable incident as having occurred under his observation:

q.p:
When the Ohio regiments, 1st and 2d, were across the Potomac, a member of one of the Cincinnati companies, spying a little darkey by the roadside, bought him of his mother for fifty cents. The "nig" went with them to the battle of Bull Run, and every time a cannon ball whizzed past he would roll himself up in a knot, and fall on the ground, hollering so as to be heard above the pain of battle.
Little darkey was terribly scared, so much so that the soldiers took compassion on him, and placed him in an ambulance.
Here, in probably as dangerous a place as could be found, the darkey thought he was perfectly safe, and commenced singing himself to sleep.
Like, the bird that hides its head and thinks it cannot be seen, the darkey thought there was no danger under a thin covering of canvas.

div4.head: Applying the Rod.
div4.p: The Medina Tribune cites the following hostile engagement between two individuals of opposite sexes as having come off in that place a few days ago:

q.p:
A whipping affair recently occurred in this village, in which a lady was the heroine.
She had been invited to attend a ball by a young man, who took another lady, making a second choice.
The slighted young lady was driven in a buggy by her young brother to the scene of the dance, and just as the faithless young man was handing his second choice into the carriage to go homes, he attacked him with a whip and lashed him soundly, to the great amusement of fifty or more persons.

div4.head: A Song Dedicated to M'Clellan.
div4.p: A Yankee married lady, who, it seems, was filled to overflowing with admiration upon reading McClellan's late speech to old Abe's minions at Alexandria, bethought herself of perpetrating the choice morceau in poetry.--The following is the result of her efforts:

lg.l: We have had our last retreat,
We have had our last retreat,
We have had our last retreat,
--McClellan's marching on,
Glory, Halle, Hallelujah, &c.
We have seen our last defeat,
We have seen our last defeat,
We have seen our last defeat,
McClellan's marching on.
Glory, Ralle, Hallelujah,&c.
You stand by me and I'll stand by you,
You stand by me and I'll stand by you,
You stand by me and I'll stand by you,
And victory shall be ours.
Glory, Ralle, Hallelujah,&c.

div3.p: What is the best line to lead a man with?--Crine-line.

div3.head: Affairs at the South.

argument.p: affairs on the Potomac — arrest of Penitentiary convicts — the System of Free Markets,"c.

div3.p: From our Southern exchanges we make up the following summary:

div4.head: Exciting Rumor Afloat.
div4.p: The Fredericksburg Herald also publishes the following:

q.p:
We have a rumor of a startling character, which we will name, but we have not been able to trace it to a responsible source, which fact we wish distinctly kept in view.
It is that information has been received from Maryland of a contemplated attack on the various batteries along the Potomac.
That a part of the "Big Fleet" is to be used in this connection.
A landing of a large body of soldiers with artillery, is to be made below Mathias Point, and this force and the fleet on the river are to move upward together, attacking in the rear and in front simultaneously, whatever force may be stationed at Mathias Point; next the batteries at Aquia Creek; and ultimately the batteries at Evansport.
The Sickles Brigade are reported as part of this force,
It is stated that Gen. McClellan has said the batteries at Evansport must be taken without regard to the cost.
These are the main features which Madam Rumor bears to us this morning from the Potomac.

Several facts, or at least that which we believe to be true, may be named in this connection, viz: That the big fleet has been divided, a part going South, the other part evidently designed for operations on the Potomac; that soldiers have been sent off from Washington intended for operations somewhere; that the fight at Leesburg was evidently with the view of drawing a large Confederate force to that quarter, thus weakening the defences of the Lower Potomac; and besides, that Gen. McClellan prides himself on his strategic ability.

div4.head: The Live Yankee and Freeborn again on the Potomac.
div4.p: The Fredericksburg Recorder, of yesterday, has the following:

q.p:
The river remained clear up to Friday last when several men-of-war returned from down the river and took up their old station off Aquia Creek, where they remain watching our batteries.
The heavy firing which was heard on several occasions towards the close of last week, and on Sunday, proceeded from Yankee war vessels, who were firing along the shore about Mathias Point, in order to discover "rebel" batteries.

In the vicinity of Evansport nothing of interest had transpired since our last until yesterday afternoon, about 2 o'clock, when the Live Yankee, the Freeborn, and two other steamers were observed to be making their way down the Potomac, but we are happy to say that they fully appreciated the maxim that "discretion is the better part of valor," and hauled to when some distance off and the vessels designated by name commenced a fire on our batteries.
Some thirty shot and shell were thrown by the enemy.
Those of the Live Yankee all fell short.
Some of the shells of the Freeborn reached, and two burst just above one of our batteries, but, providentially, did no damage.
It cannot be positively ascertained whether any of our balls reached or not, but our informant says that many of the shots ricochetted, and water was seen splashing on the deck of the Live Yankee.

On our side about twenty shots were fired and we hear the usual gratifying report that with us nobody was hurt.
After this demonstration the steamers returned up the stream, doubtless thinking it imprudent to run the gauntlet of the slight obstruction of our batteries as they are pleased to speak of them in their press reports.

div4.head: From Evansport and Aquia Creek.
div4.p: The Fredericksburg Herald, of yesterday, has the following in relation to affairs on the Potomac:

q.p: These two points on the Potomac, where we have open batteries, and the metal of whose guns have been tested by the enemy, continue to be points of interest.

The river seems to be closed to the navigation of Federal craft in the vicinity of Evansport, according to the open and frequent confessions of the enemy themselves; yet that they have successfully, though not frequently, steamed and sailed by our batteries there during the night, we do not pretend to question.
This was before the "Richmond," formerly the "George Page" hoisted the broad pennant of the Confederate States at her mast head and took position on the waters of the Potomac.

For the last week we do not believe that either steamer or sail vessel of the enemy has passed up or down the river.
Indeed, the entire flotilla was withdrawn from below the batteries, and not a sail or piece of bunting was to be seen in the river until Saturday morning, when some three or four steamers were discerned below Aquia Creek, close to the Maryland shore.

The earnest fire of Lieut. Simms, C. S. N., from off the "Richmond," shortly after her arrival at Evansport on Wednesday last; had the effect to break up the camp of the Sickles' Brigade, on the Maryland bank of the Potomac, in an unprecedentedly short time, and the Brigade at once decamped to what they considered safer quarters.
But they had not accurately calculated the range of our guns, for a few shots from the recently imported English gun again necessitated a change in their camp.
The shot and shell from this gun cleared the river entirely, and fell immediately in their camp.

On yesterday morning the Federal steamer "Yankee," which has on board a very excellent gun, steamed up the river as though the officers had determined on testing the calibre of our cannon and the skill of our gunners.--The "Yankee" kept off close to the Maryland shore, and opened up a fire on the lower batteries at Evansport.
Her shot did not reach us, and a few fires on our part showed that she was out of range.
The "Yankee" took good care to return the same route she had come, and did not attempt to pass by our batteries up the river!

div4.head: Arrest of Penitentiary convicts.
div4.p:
The fact that a number of Penitentiary convicts had escaped from the fortifications near this city on Saturday last, has already been published.
It was also announced that they had stolen and carried off with them two certificates of the City Savings' Bank, amounting to $800. The Petersburg Express, of yesday, has the following notice of their arrest:

q.p:
Evening before last, three of these convicts were arrested upon Gill street, in this city by officer Prosise; but one of them was turned loose on the recommendation of a certain party on Washington street, who told Mr. Prosise that he knew the negro to be free, and vouched in other ways for his good character.
It was not until subsequent events proved it, that the officer discovered he had turned loose one of the convicts — the very worst one of the party.
After the other two were lodged in jail, search was made for the one at large until midnight, and continued all day yesterday, but with no success up to late last evening.

The name of the party who interfered for his release.
we will not at present mention, though we are informed that he had in his possession the certificates, said to be stolen by the convicts.
They were yesterday held by one of our brokers, to be returned to the proper owner, upon identification.
It is proper to state that the fellow who was released, adopted the title of "Duke," the name signed to the certificates — which smartness he was no doubt put up to by a more intelligent head than his own. He also stole some clothing, as is indicated by the extra suit he had on at the time of his arrest.

div4.head:
[they were brought to this city yesterday.]
the System of Free markets.
div4.p:
The establishment of free markets in many of the cities South of Richmond, for the benefit of those who are not able to purchase the comforts and necessaries of life, is truly an admirable forethought in times like the present, and one which we hope the enterprising and patriotic citizens of this locality will not be long in emulating.
The following excellent and considerate suggestion is taken from the St. Joseph (Tensas parish,) Gazette. Cannot some such plan be adopted in this city?
We have no doubt, if the recommendation of the Gazette were generally agreed to, there are thousands whose contributions would not be stinted to the limit named by that journal; but even with a dime from each voter the aggregate would make a handsome sum:

There never was an institution which, during the pressing times of a people, has been productive of so much good as the Free Market in New Orleans is bestowing upon the distressed families of the volunteers, who have left that city for the war. As the winter approaches, vegetables will be less abundant, and apart from the stables, fuel will have to be supplied to the poor families, whom we cannot allow to be exposed to the cold blasts of the season, so that it must be clear to every one that soon more contributions will be required than even now. It is true that the liberality of our citizens has been taxed in very many respects, that every one is doing all he can for the good cause, and that there may be some who disagree with us as to the asking of assistance for the poor in the city when there is so much to be attended to at home.
However, what we ask is very little and we doubt not will be attended to without a single exception.
We suggest that at the coming November elections, contribution boxes he placed at all the polls wherein such man can deposit a dime for the benefit of the Free Market in New Orleans-- There is not a man who will not be able and willing to contribute that much, and if the press throughout the State will only urge this matter, or our authorities publish such a request, several thousand dollars will be easily raised, which sum will go far to relieve the suffering of many destitute families.

div4.head: Who makes the greatest sacrifice?
div4.p: "Truth is stranger than fiction," and never has the application been more strikingly demonstrated than in the following paragraph which we clip from the Mississippian:

While Gen. C. or Col. E., each worth $100,000, is receiving the adulations of the press and the people for having enlisted in the cause of liberty as high privates, let us not fall to poise the scales of even-handed justice, and weigh the respective claims which the poor and rich man hold on a grateful posterity.
Plain Mr. H., too, has enlisted as a high private.
His wife and little ones look to him alone for bread.
It he fall there are no broad acres to pour their teeming plenty into the laps of his loved ones at home, as is the case with Gen. C. or Col. E. Yet he enlists; yet he flies to the succor of a bleeding country, and runs the fearful risk of reducing his angels at home to want.
Who makes the greatest sacrifice?

div4.head: Reduction of cents.
div4.p:
We recommend the following paragraph which we clip from the Savannah Republican, to those whom it may concern in this city.--We respectfully suggest to our patriotic landlords, that (perhaps) the same reasons which dictated the propriety of a reduction of rents in our sister cities South of us, exist to us great an extent here.
Has there been an instance of such a course being pursued by any one of them?

Many of our landlords have acted most nobly towards their tenants in these times of trouble, when business is completely at a stand still, and the latter are unable to pay. Some have reduced their rent 20, some 25, and others 33 per cent., in consideration of the great falling-off in business.
In some instances parties are required to pay what they conveniently can, and give their notes for the balance.

A few hard cases — men who cannot brook the idea of a curtailed revenue, or of abridging any of their luxuries in the midst of general distress, still hold out and claim the uttermost farthing.
Of these, though, we hope there are but few, and that even they, upon a second thought, will consent to make their share of sacrifice.
They may make less money, but they curtail nothing of the comforts of life.
They will still be able to live and live well.
The real suffering in times like these, is with that class who labor for their daily bread, whose wages are necessary for their subsistence, and who have to struggle with diminished receipts and high prices combined.
There are many such and the war has aggravated the evil by drawing the support of many poor families to the tented field.

div4.head: Patriotic extract from a Confederate soldier's will to his wife.
div4.p: The following extract from the will of one our brave soldiers, we publish as an indication of their determination to discharge their whole duty:

div5.p:
--A very large part of the army is at present concentrated at this place, the whole country for miles around presenting the appearance of one unbroken encampment, and I am of the opinion that we are upon the eve of a great battle; if so, I am confident we will beat them worse than we did on the plains of Manassas, God being our helper, but it will be at the sacrifice of many a Southerner.
But who of us would not be willing to sacrifice his life upon the altar of his country, when he remembers the injuries attempted to be inflicted upon us by the Abolition shriekers of the North--when he remembers that their object is to place the negro upon an equality with the white man — when he remembers that they have invaded our country to subjugate us to the unjust demands of the tyrant who disgraces the Presidential chair, in the person of the ape, Abraham Lincoln?

If it should be my fate to fall upon the field of battle, I desire that you shall shed no unnecessary tears over my remains.
Be assured that I will fall with my face to the enemy, and remember that you, too, are called upon to make sacrifices — you have already made many — and I doubt not you would consider this the greatest of all; but, like the noble women of the South, I hope you will have the fortitude to make it cheerfully.
If it should be the case, I appoint you the executrix of my estate, without security.
I desire that all my just debts be paid, and the remainder I give to you in your own right during life, and at your death to be equally divided between our children. W. A. B.

P. S. You must preserve this letter; for, should I fall, you will have to produce it in court, and have it recorded.
You must continue to remember me in your prayers, and may God in his mercy preserve and protect you all. Don't let this make you serious, for I never was in better spirits, but I thought it due to make the very best provision in my power.
Affectionately, W. A. B.

div4.head: Confederate cattle Estray.
div4.p: Some 70 or 75 head of cattle, a portion of the drove that arrived in Petersburg on Sunday night, and destined for Norfolk, escaped from the pens in which they were confined, in that city, and thus far only 15 or 20 have been found.

div4.head: Honorable Conduct.
div4.p: The Petersburg Express, of yesterday, has the following:

q.p:
During the passage of a regiment of troops through this city a few days since, one of the soldiers, either by accident or through mischief, killed a goose, on one of our streets.
Yesterday by morning Mayor Townes received a letter from the Colonel of the regiment, written from Goldsboro', with one dollar enclosed, to indemnify the owner of the fowl.--This is a very small affair, but how powerfully does it speak.
Honesty is always the best policy.

div4.head: New Orleans markets.
div4.p: From the New Orleans Picayune, of the 26th, we take the following in regard to commercial affairs in that city:

There has been more movement in both sugar and molasses, during the past week, but every other branch of trade has continued extremely dull.
Operations in our leading staple have been on a still more limited scale.
Nothing has been done in tobacco, and very little in Western produce.
There have been, however, some variations in prices, particularly in flour, wheat, and corn, all of which have advanced in consequence of our receipts from Memphis having been to a great extent suspended, the supplies of that market being cut off by the interdiction of the commander of that military district, of the transportation of produce from the interior.
The effect of this extraordinary measure has been the most marked in flour, which has advanced from $8 to $10 per bbl. for surperfine, but it has been felt in other articles included in the interdiction, as will be seen by the details below.

The weather has been variable but seasonable.
Yesterday it was clear and cool.

Cotton.--The market has shown but little movement, the sales comprising none on Saturday, 25 bales on Monday, none on Tuesday, none on Wednesday, none yesterday, and none to-day.
There is a very limited supply offering, and holders have consequently asked fuller prices, Ordinary to Good Ordinary being held at 7½a7½c., and Low Midding to Middling at 8½a9½c. Week's receipts none; last year 67,636.
Total since Sept. 1, 1899 last year, 348,059.
Week's exports, none.
Week's exports last year, 36,461.
Total exports last year 177,394.
There have been no exports reported this year.

Sugar.--The receipts have been more liberal, and the market has exhibited a fair degree of activity the demand running mainly on the better qualities, the week's sales comprising fully 1,000 hhds., closing to-day at the following quotations: Inferior 2a3; common to good common 3a3½c.; fair to fully fair 4¼a5½c.; prime to choice 5¼a--.(none offering,) yellow clarified 6½a8¼c., and white clarified 8allc.--This includes 200 hhds. to-day at 2½a3 for inferior and ordinary, 5¼c. for good fair to fully fair, 6 for prime, 7½a8¼c. for yellow clarified, 10 for choice white, and 6 for seconds — Sales corresponding week last year, 1,000 hhds. at 7¾a8½c. for fair to fully fair.
Week's receipts, 2,436.; last year 1,225.
Total since 1st September, 6,529; last year, 2,663.
Week's exports none.

Molasses.--With more liberal supplies the market has exhibited increased activity, but ruling at easier prices until within the last day or two, since which it has shown more steadiness, the sales comprising 6,000 bbls. and 1,500 half bbls.
This includes 800 bbls. to-day at 20 for common, and 20a21 and 21½c. for prime to choice.
Also, 75 half bbls.
at 23½a24 for prime.
Poor to ordinary may be quoted at 18a20, prime at 20a21, and choice at 21½a22 Week's receipts, 6,124 bbls. and 1,782 half bbls.; last year 1,226 bbls. Total since Sept. 1, 18,261 bbls.; last year 3,102.--Week's exports, none.

Tobacco.--We hear of no further sales — Prices are nominally unchanged, but are understood to be fully up to our quotations — Lugs, factory, 3a4½ Lugs, planters, 3½a5; leaf, inferior to common, 5¼a6; leaf, fair, 6¼a7¼; leaf, fine, 7½a9; leaf, choice and selections, 9½a12. Week's receipts, none; last year, 211 hhds. Total receipts since the 1st of September, 233 hhds.; last year, 1783.
Exports, none.
Total exports, 000 hhds.; last year, 7,975.

Flour.--The partial suspension of receipts from Memphis, as noticed in our preliminary remarks, has so much diminished the supply, that prices have advanced $2a2 50 per bbl., the sales up to last evening comprising 6,000 bbls. at $8 50a10 for superfine, and $9a11 for extra.
Today 1,800 bbls. extra sold at $11.--Week's receipts 2,137 bbls. Exports none.

Wheat.--The sales comprise 276 sacks inferior red on Saturday at $1 25, and 383 red yesterday at $1 50.
Week's receipts, 457 sacks from Memphis Exports none.

Corn.--With limited receipts prices have further improved 12½a15 per bushel, the sales up to last evening comprising barely 3500 sacks at 35c,a$1.12½, closing at outside figures for white.
To-day we did not hear of a single sale.
Week's receipts, 2,513 sacks. Exports none.

Coffee.--The stock is exhausted, and we have no sales to notice.
Imports none.
Stock none, against 74,269 last year.

div3.head: Latest from Missouri.
div3.p:
Memphis, Oct. 29.--The Appeal, of this city, has reliable advices which announce that Gen. Price was at Neosho on the 18th inst.
His army was in good fighting condition, and Gen. McCulloch was in close proximity, and daily receiving large accessions.
Their combined forces will outnumber any force that Fremont can bring against them.
The opinion prevailed, that Gen. Fremont was making a desperate effort to retrieve his failing fortunes.
Gen. Price's retrograde movement was strategical and his troops are now amply supplied with ammunition, and determined to stand.

Jeff. Thompson is in Memphis.
He left his command safe.
It was reported, at St. Louis, that 300 rebels had congregated at Fulton, with the design of crossing the river, and burning the Orange bridge.

div3.head:
Later from Europe.
arrival of city of Baltimore.
Earl Russell on American affairs — commercial, &c.
div3.p: St. Johns, Oct. 25.--The steamer City of Baltimore has been intercepted off Cape Race, with Liverpool advices to the 16th instant.

The Earl Russell, in a speech at New Castle, deplored the state of affairs in America.
He said that England had no reason to interfere, but should watch the course of affairs, and, if able, interfere for the cause of freedom and humanity.
He said he could see no harmony either by the surrender or subjugation of the South.
Breadstuffs closed buoyant.
Provisions closed dull.
Consols 92½a92¼.

div3.head: Alabama Legislature--Governor's message
div3.p:
Montgomery, Ala.,., Oct. 20. --The Legislature of Alabama met in this city on yesterday.
Mr. Patton, of Lauderdale, was elected President of the Senate, and Mr. Crenshaw, of Butler, Speaker of the House.

The Governor in his message to-day says, that if the General Assembly can devise a plan to pay the war tax without collecting it from the people at present, he recommends that it be adopted; but if no satisfactory and constitutional plan can be devised he thinks it best to make no change.
He says that the State of Alabama has now 27,000 troops in the service of the Confederacy, and other regiments are being organized.
He congratulates the State that all its citizens are patriotically united in sustaining the movements in operation to establish the independence of the Southern Confederacy.

div3.head: Gen, Fremont and the Administration.
div3.p:
Washington, Oct. 25.--Gen. Fremont gives the Administration much trouble.
The Cabinet had a meeting on the 23d inst., and some favored depriving him of his command immediately, and ordering him to Washington, to be tried by a court-martial.
The matter was left with the President to decide, who finds it a very difficult question to settle, as it involves not only great pecuniary interests to the Government, but perhaps immediate and important military results.

div3.head: A Federal steamer fired into.
div3.p:
Cairo, Oct. 24.--The Government steamer March Cook was fired upon last night by 300 cavalry.
About 100 shots were fired into her, wounding one man. The fire was returned and one rebel was crippled.
The rebels followed the boat several miles, but she escaped.

div3.head: From Kentucky.
div3.p:
Nashville, Oct. 29.--The latest Louisville papers report seventeen regiments of infantry, three companies of cavalry, and one artillery company from Indiana.
There are now in Kentucky 18,178 troops from Indiana.

div3.head: From Wilmington.
div3.p: Wilmington, N. C., Oct. 30, 9 o'clock at night.--Nothing has been seen yet of the Federal fleet which left Hampton Roads a few days ago. All is quiet here.

div3.head: Eleven Federal vessels at the mouth of the Mississippi.
div3.p: Mobile, Oct. 30--Eleven Lincoln men-of-war, and one transport steamer, are at the mouth of the Mississippi.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 20, Number 102, page 4.

div3.head: Kentucky, where art thou?
div3.p: Inscribed to Col. R. C. Wintersmith, of Louisville, for his gallant efforts in behalf of Southern Independence.

lg.l: Still is gentle peace retreating
From her proud and venal foe--
Still a nation's heart is beating
With a nation's mighty woe,
When the storm was rising o'er us,
And our pilot seemed to steer
On the rocks and shoals before us,
Then our souls grew wild with fear.
Wife and children — home's sweet pleasures--
All were on that wave washed deck,
And we knew the world's broad treasures
Could not pay us for the wreck.
While our gallant ship was groaning
Like a giant struck with pain,
We on bended knees were moaning--
Weeping tears that fell in vain.
Lightning o'er the while foam brightened--
Nearer came the fatal shoal
And our pilot, weak and frightened,
Steered us like a driveling fool.
Sails were shivered — spare were broken--
Bright stars faded one by one--
Sum'er fell — then martyred Jackson--
And the crazy ship went down.
Undismared we build another,
Beautiful and strong and trim,
And we placed a gallant brother
Southern-hearted at the helm.
Then the Pilot — swearing loudly
Stamped his foot with angry frown,
But the Stars and Bars waved proudly,
And our gallant ship sailed on.
Still he threatened to harass us
Into meek submissive mood,
And we answered from Manassas
In a message sealed with blood.
Fiercer grew the wild contention--
Fell hit sacrilegious hand,
With a murderer's foul intention,
On our little Maryland.
By the jeers with which he hissed her,
Not a Southern blade shall rest,
Tid we've laid our darling sister
Safely on her mother's breast.
In the West the foe exulted,
And Missouri's standing now,
Like a lofty queen insulted
With a crown upon her brow.
Will her proud form wear the fetters
Forged by such a mongrel horde?
Go and read the fatal letters
Traced on Lyon's broken sword.
We have sent to you bright heaven
One united, deathless vow,
That our chains shall all be riven,
And, Kentucky, where art thou?
Should thy sons as foemen pass us,
We would bow a stricken head,
Sad as when at dark Manassas
We were gathering up our dead.
On the day that madly dashes
All by hopes of proud release,
Send us Henry Clay's pure ashes,
That his soul may rest in peace.

div3.head: Runaway
div3.p:
--From the subscriber, in the city of Richmond, on Sunday, the 27th inst., my Negro Boy Van. The said Boy is about 17 years old badly grown quite black; had on when he left, dark pants, grayish coats, dark vest.
A suitable reward will be paid for his delivery to me on Franklin street below the Exchange.
When last seen he was on the Basin and at the American Hotel.
[oc 30--3t*] F. Morsan.

div3.head: Ranaway
div3.p:
--From the Bellevue Hospital, a servant man named Oliver.
He is about 30 years old, a mulatto, and has a scar on the left side of his neck; very smart; had a gray suit and hat. Five dollars reward will be paid for his apprehension.
[oc 30--ts] James Bolton, M. D.

div3.head: Ranaway.--fifty dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the jail of Thos. Jones, of this place, on Monday, 21st of October, a negro man, named James dark brown color, 20 years old, and near six feet high.
I will pay the above reward for said negro if taken out of this city, or $5 if found in it. He had on a black suit when he left; also, a military over coat.
To be delivered to E. H. Stokes, Richmond, Va.
oc 28--6t* J. A. Burdett.

div3.head: Ran away--$100 reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away, on Monday, a Negro Boy, named Essex; about five feet eight inches high; black; stammers slightly; about twenty or twenty-two years old; weight about 150 pounds; formerly belonged to Capt. John Wright, of Plain View, P. O., King and Queen county, Va. The above reward will be paid on his delivery to me at my office, in this city.
He may be making his way to West Point, Va. He has a wife in that neighborhood.
His upper teeth are dark, from tarter on them.
oc 22--ts Benjamin Davis.

div3.head: Runaway--fifty dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Runaway, on the 5th of August, my Negro Woman, named Betty; about 28 years old, five feet four inches high, black, who was hired to Joseph Davis, on Broad street. She has a mark on the face, in consequence of a mustard plaster she had on, which place is darker.--She has children in Cumberland county, where I bought her of Mr. J. M. Price.
She is probably in this city, or has made her way to Mr. Price's. I will give the above reward, if delivered to me here or if lodged in jail in the county or city.
oc 7--1m* Joseph Stern.

div3.head: Request made to Physicians.
div3.p:
--It is respectfully requested that the Physicians of Richmond will report at the office, corner of Broad and 9th streets, such officers and soldiers under their charge as are quartered in private families, hotels, and boarding-houses — stating their condition, where quartered, and, as far as practicable, the regiment and company to which they belong.
This information will greatly promote the public service.

All officers and soldiers quartered in private families, hotels, and boarding-houses, who have been sick, but are not attended by any physician, will report themselves as above, stating their condition, location, company, and regiment.
div3.closer:
Jno. H. Winder.
oc 10--ts Brig. General

div3.head: Notice.

list.item: I.--Persons who are sending clothing and supplies to troops in the field, are requested to mark distinctly on the package (with marking ink) the name of the party for whom intended, the Regiment to which he belongs, and the place of Destinations, care of Quartermaster at Richmond, to whom the usual railroad receipt should be forwarded by the shipper.

II.--Many packages arrive at the depots of the railroads in Richmond with paper marks rubbed off; of course their destination cannot be known by the Quartermaster.
Others are imperfectly marked, and cannot be identified.
III.--All articles deposited at the Quartermaster's Office in Richmond, for shipment, must be left there before 3 o'clock, P. M., to insure their shipment on that day.

div3.closer:
W. E. Warren
oc 19--ts Capt. and Ass't Q. M.

div3.head: Caution.
div3.p: --No one is authorized to collect Virginia arms in this city, or elsewhere in this State, unless they show written authority from me.

This notice is not of course to interfere with the authority of the Adjutant General of the State in any order be may have issued, or may issue hereafter upon this subject; but is given to prevent impositions by those having no authority, and who make no return to this office.
div3.closer:
C. Dimmock,
oc 14--ts Col. of Ordnance of Virginia.
City papers copy.

div3.head:
Ordnance Department of Va.,
Richmond, Aug. 7, 1861.
div3.p:
Notice — It is very desirable that all corps, communities and individuals in the State, having arms of any kind — beyond those absolutely necessary for their immediate use — should return the same to this Department as soon as possible that they may be overhauled and thoroughly repaired.
Address,
div3.closer:
C. Dimmock, Colonel,
au 8--ts Chief of Ordnance of Virginia.
